p: Influenza A virus (IAV) is a member of the family Orthomyxoviridae. IAV has been responsible for numerous yearly epidemics and for at least four pandemics during the past ~100 years; estimates are that more than 100 million people have died from infection during this time period [ 1, 2]. IAV is a small enveloped virus with a genome of eight segments of negative-sense single-stranded RNA that encode 10–15 proteins, depending on the virus strain [ 3, 4, 5]. IAV is serologically categorized by two surface proteins: The hemagglutinin (HA), of which there are currently 18 types (H1–H18), and neuraminidase (NA), of which there currently are 11 types (N1–11) [ 3, 6].
